g.text: • supports the token exchange extension of OAuth2
• publishes its metadata on a URL /.well-known/oauth-authorization-server
• also acts as RqP's Identity Provider
• is registered at AS-RqP as a public or confidential client
• acts as a Relying Party in a RqP's Identity Provider in order to obtain an an access_token_with_user_claims
RO has set up RS and registers his resource at AS-RO to get resource_uri and sets policies
to the resource sets with the authorization server to indicate who can access the resources.
1. Send HTTP request to resource_uri with no access token
2. Request a permission ticket and resource claims token
AS-RO generates the permission ticket itself (ticket is a random NONCE) and the resource claims token,
which is bound to the permission ticket through a permission ticket hash.
The resource claims token contains these claims:
issuer is the URI that identifies who issues the resource claims token
ts is the timestamp of when the permission ticket was created
audience is the URI that identifies the resource server
email_address is the email address of the resource owner
3. Return the permission ticket and resource claims token
4. Return 401 with the permission ticket and resource claims token
5. Request an identity claims token (token exchange request)
1. select the email_address claim from resource_claims_token
2. bootstrap discovery of AS-RO url from email address via WebFinger;
if this doesn't work, build well-known url using domain part of email_address
3. compare AS-RO url with the iss claim from resource_claims_token
AS-RqP generates the identity claims token, which contains these claims:
3. select the email_address claim from user_claims
4. bootstrap discovery of AS-RqP url from email address via WebFinger;
if this doesn't work, build well-known url using domain part of email_address
5. compare AS-RqP url with the iss claim from resource_claims_token
10. Return HTTP response typically with 200, 201 status code
